text.tspan: Genetically modied crops are key to meeting the
challenge of providing sufcient and affordable
food and fuel from plant crops for a world with an
expanding population and a changing climate. The
rapidly evolving genetic knowledge of plant cells,
enabled by the tools of molecular biology, is likely to
accelerate during the next 15-20 years, providing the
means to increase the yield of major food crops. The
promising results of ongoing research to relate key
plant traits to a plant’s genetic structure indicate that
the application of modern molecular plant breeding
and transgenic technologies have the potential to
signicantly enhance global food security in the next
15-20 years. However, this group of plant technologies
faces some of the most intense regulatory and
public pressures of any new technologies, which
makes widespread adoption of any of these potential
Advances in molecular biology applied to crop
development have enabled scientists to identify genes
that express important agronomic traits in crop
transfer of genes from one plant species to another to
New resource technologies can also enhance water
efciencies. In addition, they can increase the
availability of energy, not only through highly
successful enhanced oil and natural gas extractions
resulting from use of hydraulic fracturing (see box
on page 37), but also through alternative energy
sources such as solar and wind power and biofuels.
the potential effects of these technologies on the
environment, climate, and health well known to
China, India, and Russia—countries that have critical
needs for key resources—are expected to realize
substantial rewards in being the rst countries to
Being rst may allow private and state-owned Chinese,
Indian, and Russian resource companies to establish
strong global competitive positions. Aside from being
cost competitive, any expansion or adoption of both
during the next 15-20 years will largely depend on
social acceptance and the direction and resolution of
